sections.subtitle: The verb honā/होना simple present & past

body.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"heading-4","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Verb होना ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"honā","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" (to be)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The simple present tense conjugation of the verb होना","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" honā ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"is not gendered. However, in the simple past tense the verb होना ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"honā","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" is conjugated along gender lines. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"While the masculine plural form is often used across genders in some parts of India and hence could conceivably be used as a “gender neutral\" expression, it is still problematic for many as technically it is the male voice and it could be perceived as such.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The proposed non-binary simple past tense conjugation of the verb होना ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"honā","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" found in the files below is an attempt to address the limitations posed by the gendered nature of verb conjugations in Hindi.
